author: pierre@roux01.fr
message: Add sign inference on type as a last resort
body:
Previously e%:sgn was failing when an unknown (or no, i.e., for which
no canonical instance is registered) operation was encountered in the
expression e, now some sign information can be inferred from the type
of the unknown sub expression.

This is generalizing the canonical instance already existing for the
type nat.

This is needed in https://github.com/math-comp/analysis/pull/375 to be
able to infer that `|x|%E is non negative when nothing is known on x.

author: pierre@roux01.fr
body:
Otherwise, we didn't know wether 0 should be abstracted as >=0 or <=0.
The former made max(0, _) fail to be recognized as <=0 while the
latter would break min(0, _) similarly.

author: pierre@roux01.fr
body:
`expr%:nng` was failing when `expr%:pos` was working because the more
precise type `{posnum _}` was infered instead of `{nonneg _}`.

author: pierre@roux01.fr
body:
It was requiring an exact abstract value,
now any more-precise abstract value also works.

For instance `unify AnySign NonNeg` was failing
because NonNeg was too precise, whereas
`unify_r AnySign NonNeg` now works.

This is currently useless because one was only asking for most-precise
abstract values, but should become useful in the future.

* Add lemmas on subtraction of extended values

- The naming scheme for the l{t,e}e_{,d}sub{,e}{r,l}_add{r,l} lemmas is
  now as follows:
  + sub{r,l} when the subtracted var must be a fin_num
  + sube{r,l} when the subtracted var can be an extended value
    (and another var must be a fin_num)

author: Yves.Bertot@inria.fr
body:
- The definition of shift is moved from landau.v to normedtype.v
 - Lemmas used in the proof that inverse functions are continuous are
   also moved to normedtype.v

   Generic lemmas (only slightly related to continuous or inverse functions)
   * bound_itvE1 (conditions for the bounds of an interval to be in the interval)
   * nearN, near_in_itv
   * subset_itv_oo_cc (this should be a math-comp lemma)
   * subset_ball_prop_in_itv (maybe a better name should be found)
   * prop_in_and (this should be a coq/ssr lemma)

   Specific lemmas about inverse of continuous functions, some of these lemmas
   are concerned with closed input intervals (these lemmas have the prefix
   "segment" in their name); some are concerned with any form of interval
   (these lemmas have the prefix "itv" in their name); some of these lemmas
   work near a given point.
   * segment_continuous_inj_le, segment_left_inverse_increasing,
     segment_inverse_increasing_continuous
   * itv_continuous_inj_le, itv_continuous_inj_ge, itv_continuous_inj_monotone
   * continuous_inverse, continuous_can_sym

   Some symmetric lemmas could be added: segment_continuous_inj_ge
   (inspired from itv.*ge) and segment_left_inverse_decreasing

 - normedtype.v also contains one application: the proof that sqrt
   is continuous.

 - The file inverse_continuous.v still exists, but it is destined to be removed.

author: reynald.affeldt@aist.go.jp
message: Main theorems about sequences and series and examples
body:
Definitions:
- `[sequence E]_n` is a special notation for `fun n => E`
- `series u_` is the sequence of partial sums
- `[normed S]` is the series of absolute values, if S is a series
- `harmonic` is the name of a sequence, apply `series` to them to get the series.

Example: `cvg [normed series (geometric a z)]`
  states the absolute convergence of the series \sum_(n > 0) |a z^n|.

Theorems:
- lots of helper lemmas to prove convergence of sequences
- convergence of harmonic sequence
- convergence of a series implies convergence of a sequence
- absolute convergence implies convergence of series

Co-Authored-By: Cyril Cohen <cyril.cohen@inria.fr>

author: cohen@crans.org
body:
- near tactics proof flow is more natural.
  + near=> x behaves like an intro for \forall x \near F, P x
  + and near: x like a discharge, so that the proof obligation related to it immediately follows the tactic call (it used to be delayed to after end_near)
  + Need to replace "Qed." by "Grab Existential Variables. all: end_near. Qed." until a feature request is made in Coq
- speedup of typeclasses inference using some opacity

author: cohen@crans.org
body:
- begin_near x becomes near=> x
- begin_near2 x y becomes near=> x y
- near becomes near:
- have near F x becomes near F have x
- disclaimers:
  + near=> is *not* followed by an intro pattern but just one or two variables
  + near: is *not* followed by a "revert" parttern but just one variable.
